resources.string: "Game created by Petter Säterskog. Challenges designed by Alast, bwisialo, Nayus and Petter. In case you get stuck:"

"Many thanks to Alast, bwisialo, Nayus and Eric Säterskog who designed some of the challenges and gave invaluable feedback.
Huge thanks to all beta testers and Cell Lab Forum contributors!
All sound and music created by Danilov Sound," danilovsound.com
These settings are for advanced use. Setting them inappropriately might make Cell Lab crash/run extremely slowly.

Saving your genome lets you reuse it in another challenge or send it to a friend.

Cell Lab is provided as a completely free app. There are no payments for features and no ads. If you would like to show your appreciation to the developer, consider donating an amount of your choice below. A combination of buttons can be used.
If you would like to make a donation to the developer of this game you can do so in the \"About\" page of the main menu.
"Cell will split once its mass is: "

N.B. This file contains a genetic sequence and should be opened with appropriate software. Download Android app "

"New findings!
N.B. This sample contains live organisms and should be opened with appropriate equipment. Download Android app "

"This sets what amount of signal substance Neurocyte signalling pathway "
"This sets what channel Neurocyte signalling pathway "
When sensing cells of a certain color, this is the amount of blue in that color.
When sensing cells of a certain color, this is the amount of green in that color.
This indicates what amount to output when it senses a smell.
This indicates what channel to output to when it senses a smell.
When sensing cells of a certain color, this is the amount of red in that color.
When sensing cells of a certain color, this is how far away the actual color of the cell can be from the settings above.
This indicates what \"smell\" this cell is sensitive to.
Increasing this keeps the daughter cells further apart, allowing cells to pass above the adhesin connection.
This sets the speed with which touching objects are dragged relative to this cell on its left side.
This sets the speed with which touching objects are dragged relative to this cell on its right side
The cell membrane will be more susceptible to fusion if both gametes are compatible.
The cytoskeleton helps the cell keep its shape when under pressure. A higher setting means more resources are needed to create the cell but it can keep its shape better.
The cell will not split if it is connected to this many or more other cells.
If this cell is the larger of the two cells that fuse, then this is the mode the zygote will end up in.
Each cell split removes a telomere. A cell with 0 telomeres die. The number of telomeres is reset to the number specified by this option when two gametes fuse.

Allow Ad to store image in Picture gallery?
When enabled, this will indicate cell type abbreviations next to mode settings in the genome editor.

You can set the environment of the cells under your microscope using the settings on this page. Most settings are supposed to be self-explanatory but a few requires explanations and they are given below.

Radiation: Radiation will damage your cells and introduce random mutations. A small amount of radiation can help your cells evolve into a stronger species, a very high amount will quickly ruin the genome and might kill your cells.

Only point mutations: Checking this will limit the mutations to small changes to your genomes. The cell types or modes of children will for example not be changed whereas the continuous parameters like split mass can be changed.

Dynamic friction: This is the friction coefficient cells experience while moving.

Static friction: This is the friction coefficient cells experience while still.

Viscosity: This sets the amount of Stokes drag experienced by moving cells.

Salinity: A low salinity will make your cells spend a lot of energy keeping their salt-balance. A higher value will let them survive longer without any energy source.

Density: A low substrate density will make your cell sink when gravity is turned on, a high substrate density will make your cells float when gravity is turned on.

Density gradient: A density gradient will make the density higher at the substrate bottom and lower at the top.

Nutrient coating: This gives nutrients a lipid coating that has to be removed before they can be eaten.

Nitrates: This sets how fast cells absorb nitrates from the environment. All cells consume nitrates when they split and secrocytes consume it continuously. Nitrocytes are necessary if this is set too low.

"The two daughter cells that result after this cell splits will be connected by glue called adhesin if this box is ticked.
This does two things: \u0009- The daughter cells stay together \u0009- They can transport nutrients between them.
The properties of this connection can be tuned with the properties Adhesin stiffness, Nutrient priority and the check box Prioritize below."

"Change the amount of blue in the color of cells in this mode.
Note that this does not affect the behavior of your cells in any way"

The most important property of each cell mode is what type of cell it is. Each type of cell only has one single function it can carry out so an organism that depends on many functions thus needs many cells of different types.

The types and their functions are:

Phagocyte: These cells get chemical energy from eating particles in the environment.

Flagellocyte: These cells have flagella that propel them.

Photocyte: These cells convert sunlight to chemical energy

Devorocyte: These cells suck nutrients from other cells upon touching them.

Lipocyte: These cells store energy chemically in lipids.

Keratinocyte: These cells protect themselves and directly connected cells from hostile cells.

Buoyocyte: These cells have a bubble of a fluid of tunable density.

Glueocyte: These cells make adhesin connections to other cells or the environment upon touch.

Virocyte: These cells inserts a copy of their own genomes into other cells upon touching them.

Nitrocyte: These cells fixate atmospheric N2 to NH3.

Myocyte: These are muscle cells that can contract, bend and lift other cells as a response to signal substances.

Neurocyte: These cells can regulate signal molecule concentrations.

Senseocyte: These cells can smell the concentration of substances in its environment.

Stereocyte: These cells can sense their left-right gradient of smells in the environment.

Secrocyte: These cells can emit substances to its environment.

Stemocyte: These cells can change into other modes when certain signal substance concentrations are high or low.

Gamete: These cells can fuse with other compatible gametes to form new cells with a random combination of the two gametes genomes.

Ciliocyte: These cells are covered with cilia so they do not slip easily. They can independently move the cilia on the left and right sides.

Osteocyte: These cells have very stiff adhesin and a strong cytoskeleton for no additional energy cost. They are resistant to HCN, Protease and can protect themselves from Devrocytes.

"With this slider you can choose what way daughter cell 1 is facing after this cell splits. The arrow on each cell indicates what angle it is facing.
An angle of 0° means that daughter 1 will be facing towards daughter 2. Increasing the angle rotates it counter-clockwise unless the splitting cell is mirrored, in this case the angle is defined clockwise."

"Use this setting to choose what mode daughter 1 will be in when cells of this mode split.
Any cell can be in one of 40 different modes. Each mode has different properties that you can set. Two of the properties are what modes the daughter cells will be in when the cell splits.
If your first cell is in mode 1 and it splits to two cells in mode 1, then all you cells will always be in mode 1. If on the other hand it splits into two cells in mode 2 and they further split into two cells each in mode 1, then you will end up with just cells in mode 1 and 2. It is in these cases just necessary to specify the properties of mode 1 or 1 and 2 respectively since these are the only modes your cells will be in.
The properties of the other modes are though carried on generation after generation of your cells even if they are not expressed so if some useful feature of an organism is coded there, it might surface anyways if your environment contains radiation so that your cells mutate once in a while. This happens in nature as well, many parts of e.g. the human genome do not describe any proteins used in the body."

"With this slider you can choose what way daughter cell 2 is facing after this cell splits.
An angle of 0° means that daughter 2 will be facing away from daughter 1. Increasing the angle rotates it counter-clockwise unless the splitting cell is mirrored, in this case the angle is defined clockwise."

"Use this setting to choose what mode daughter 2 will be in when cells of this mode split.
Any cell can be in one of 40 different modes. Each mode has different properties that you can set. Two of the properties are what modes the daughter cells will be in when the cell splits.
If your first cell is in mode 1 and it splits to two cells in mode 1, then all you cells will always be in mode 1. If on the other hand it splits into two cells in mode 2 and they further split into two cells each in mode 1, then you will end up with just cells in mode 1 and 2. It is in these cases just necessary to specify the properties of mode 1 or 1 and 2 respectively since these are the only modes your cells will be in.
The properties of the other modes are though carried on generation after generation of your cells even if they are not expressed so if some useful feature of an organism is coded there, it might surface anyways if your environment contains radiation so that your cells mutate once in a while. This happens in nature as well, many parts of e.g. the human genome do not describe any proteins used in the body."

"This setting only applies to Buoyocytes. Using it you can adjust the density of this cell. It will then sink or float depending on whether this density is higher or lower than that of the surrounding fluid (if a gravitational field is present).
Note that the mass is unaffected by this."

"All cells in e.g. the human body contain the same DNA but a brain cell and a muscle cell behave very differently. This is referred to as different \"modes\" of a cell in this app. The genome of each cell consists of 40 modes with different properties. Use this selector to choose what mode to edit. The properties below all correspond to the chosen mode.
The radio button \"Initial\" can be used to change what mode your cell starts in."

"Change the amount of green in the color of cells in this mode.
Note that this does not affect the behavior of your cells in any way"

"Pressing this radio button makes the current mode the \"initial\" mode.
What mode is initial is not important for the organism in the wild, it is just a means of choosing what mode cells should initially be in when shown in the preview window or placed under the microscope.
When a cell is copied from the microscope to the genome editor (top choice in \"Load\"-button menu) the mode the cell was in will be taken as the initial."

"If this cell is connected with adhesin to another cell when it split then daughter 1 will retain this adhesin connection if this box is ticked.
Note that daughter 1 must end up on the side where the adhesin connection is for this to work."

"If this cell is connected with adhesin to another cell when it split then daughter 2 will retain this adhesin connection if this box is ticked.
Note that daughter 2 must end up on the side where the adhesin connection is for this to work."

"Checking this check box makes daughter 1 of cells in this mode mirrored with respect to its parent. This means that if a cell is mirrored its daughter 1 would not get mirrored and vice versa.
All angles are measured counter-clockwise by default but if a cell is mirrored all angles (split angle, child 1 angle, child 2 angle) are defined clockwise instead.
This property can be useful to make mirror-symmetric organisms without having to use many different cell modes with fine-tuned splitting angles."

"Checking this check box makes daughter 2 of cells in this mode mirrored with respect to its parent. This means that if a cell is mirrored its daughter 2 would not get mirrored and vice versa.
All angles are measured counter-clockwise by default but if a cell is mirrored all angles (split angle, child 1 angle, child 2 angle) are defined clockwise instead.
This property can be useful to make mirror-symmetric organisms without having to use many different cell modes with fine-tuned splitting angles."
The muscle bending pulls adhesin connection in the front and rear to either the left or right of the Myocyte.
The muscle contraction pulls adhesin connection in the front and rear of the Myocyte towards its center.
The muscle lift will lift cells either in the front or rear of the Myocyte and thereby lowering their friction against the substrate.

"Cells connected with adhesin can transport nutrients between them. The flow of nutrients between two connected cells is proportional to the weighted difference between their masses. The weights are the priorities of the opposite cells.
This means that nutrients flow from more massive cells to less massive ones and from cells with low priority to cells of high priority. An equilibrium will be reached where cells of higher priority have larger masses.
If both cells have high priorities the equilibrium will be the same as if they both have low priorities, but it will be reached faster."

"Change the amount of red in the color of cells in this mode.
Note that this does not affect the behavior of your cells in any way"

"This specifies what substance to secrete.
Food/Coated Food smell/Light sense activator/Wall sense activator will affect nearby Senseocytes and Stereocytes just like the corresponding real stimuli would. They work by emitting substances that more strongly attach to the corresponding receptors and can thus give stronger signals than the natural stimuli.
Cyanide will kill unprotected organisms upon touch.
Lipase breaks down lipids on food particles so they can be eaten by phagocytes. This also hurts all but the Keratinocytes slightly since it breaks down the cell membrane.
Protease breaks adhesin connections if it touches two connected cells simultaneously.
Signal substances will diffuse to cells on touch. The - signs indicate a signal substance inhibitor."
Checking this makes all angles snap to multiples of 15° and all other values to one of 25 discrete levels.

"With this slider you can set at what angle this cell splits at. The dashed lines in the preview show where the cells will split.
Each cell is facing a specific direction (indicated by arrow), the initial cell is always facing to the right both in the preview window and when placed under the microscope. A split angle of 0° means that the cell splits perpendicular to the direction it is facing, daughter 1 will end up in this cells rear and daughter 2 will end up in the front.
Increasing the split angle will rotate the line of splitting counter-clockwise, unless this is a mirrored cell, in that case the split angle is defined clockwise."

"The mass of each cell is proportional to the amount of chemical energy they have. Cells grow when they get more energy than they consume and shrink otherwise.
When a cell's mass is larger than the split mass of the mode it is in it will split into two daughter cells.
A cell can not split until it is 30 min old so if this mass is reached before then it will not split until both requirements are met simultaneously."
The split ratio dictates how the mass of cells in this mode is distributed among the two daughter cells when it splits.

"When a cell is in a mode with this box checked it will receive an increase in nutrient priority when it is running dangerously low in nutrients.
This can be used to make sure that cells in an organism that have low nutrient priority will not give away their very last nutrients and die.
If cells in a certain mode are not essential and perhaps superfluous in an event of starvation it might be useful to untick this box."
When the path 1 signal is above .5, then the Stemocyte will differentiate into this mode.
When the path 2 signal is above .5, then the Stemocyte will differentiate into this mode.
When this signal is above .5, then the Stemocyte will differentiate into the specified mode for path 1.
When this signal is above .5, then the Stemocyte will differentiate into the specified mode for path 2.

This setting dictates how stiff the adhesin connections made when cells in this mode splits are. A high stiffness makes the daughter cells have a similar relative orientation to each other as when they were born. A lower value lets them rotate almost freely about the connection point.
This setting only applies to Flagellocytes. Using it you can adjust the intensity of the flagellum movements. Faster movements will make an organisms swim faster but it will also consume more energy.

"This setting only applies to Virocytes. Using it you can choose which mode a Virocyte should copy into the victim cell.
A Virocyte copies part of its genome into another cell upon touching it. It copies the mode selected by this setting (and 2 generations of descendant modes) into the same modes of the victim cell.
Example: Virocyte copies from mode M5. Mode M5 of Virocyte splits to M4 and M3, which respectively split to M2, M2 and M3, M3. Then these copies will be done: Virocyte → Victim M5 → M5 M4 → M4 M3 → M3 M2 → M2 "
